facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 164 of 1970 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 164 of 1970. Appeal by special leave

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from Gujarat High Court judgment dated 3rd-4th December 1969 in Criminal Appeal No. 295 of 1966.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the Judgment and order dated the 3rd 4th December, 1969 of the Gujarat High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 295 of 1966.

facts.text: Charge framed on 21-9-1967 against appellant for being found on 31 March 1967 at 9.30 p.m. in State Transport Corporation Workshop at Naroda, Ahmedabad, as foreigner from Pakistan permitted to stay till 20 September 1958.

anchor.surface_text: That you on or about the 31st day of March 1967 at about 9.30 p.m. were found in State Transport Corporation Workshop at Naroda in Ahmedabad, and you are a foreigner and you had companye from Pakistan and you had been permitted to stay in India till 20th September, 1958,

facts.text: Permit issued to respondent No. 19904 dated 6-12-1957 allowing stay till 20 September 1958.

anchor.surface_text: by Assistant Secretary to the Government of Bombay and did number depart from India before expiring of that permit issued to you by No. 19904 dated 6-12-1967 before the date 20th September 1958

facts.text: Appellant arrested while working in Baroda Central State Transport Workshop as Pakistani national who came to India in 1955 on Pakistani passport.

anchor.surface_text: showing that the appellant was working in Baroda Central State Transport Workshop when he was arrested as a companysequence of the information that he was a Pakistani national who had companye to India in 1955 on a Pakistani passport.

facts.text: Respondent produced Pakistani passport Ex.11 dated 8 September 1955.

anchor.surface_text: The accused had produced his Pakistani passport  Ex. 11  dated 8th September, 1955.

facts.text: Respondent made visa application to High Commissioner for India in Pakistan on 10 October 1955 stating he migrated from India to Pakistan in 1950.

anchor.surface_text: The prosecution had also relied upon an application for a visa made by the accused to the High Commissioner for India in Pakistan on 10th October, 1955, in which he had, inter alia, stated that he had migrated from India to Pakistan in 1950.

facts.text: Respondent born at Dhandhuka, Gujarat on 15 May 1936.

anchor.surface_text: The accused-respondent had produced credible evidence to prove that, he was born at Dhandhuka in the State of Gujarat on 15th May, 1936

facts.text: Respondent lived at Dhandhuka and attended school until 1952, then moved to Ahmedabad with father.

anchor.surface_text: that, he was living at Dhandhuka and attendee school there until 1952 when he moved to Ahmedabad with his father

facts.text: Respondent went to Pakistan as minor in anger after quarrel with father who drove him out.

anchor.surface_text: and, that he had gone to Pakistan in a state of anger while he was a minor, after a quarrel with his father who had driven him out of his house.

facts.text: Respondent denied intention of settling in Pakistan.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent denied that he had the intention of settling down in Pakistan.

facts.text: Respondent regretted leaving India within six months, tried to come back but needed Pakistani passport.

anchor.surface_text: He asserted that within six months of his arrival in Pakistan he regretted having left India and tried to companye back to his home. He alleged that, as he was unable to companye home without a Pakistani passport,

facts.text: Respondent claimed Indian citizen on 26 January 1950 and never migrated to Pakistan.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent asserted that he was an Indian citizen when the Constitution came into force on 26th January, 1950, and that he had companytinued to be an Indian citizen thereafter as he had never migrated to Pakistan.

facts.text: Judicial Magistrate acquitted respondent holding he proved Indian citizen who never migrated.

anchor.surface_text: The judicial Magistrate had acquitted the respondent after examining the cases set up by the two sides and holding that the respondent had proved that he was an Indian citizen who had never, in fact migrated to Pakistan.

facts.text: Gujarat High Court upheld acquittal, confirmed respondent Indian citizen on 26 January 1950, minor when visited Pakistan.

anchor.surface_text: In an appeal against the acquittal the High Court of Gujarat had upheld the acquittal and companyfirmed the finding that the appellant was an Indian citizen when the Constitution came into force on 26th January, 1950. It had also held that the appellant was a minor when he visited Pakistan.

facts.text: Courts found respondent went to Pakistan in 1953-54 after Constitution commencement.

anchor.surface_text: the finding of the Trial Court as well as the High Court, on the evidence before them was that the appellant had. as he asserted, gone to Pakistan in 1953-54 which was after the companymencement of the Constitution.

facts.text: Prosecution case set up migration before 26 January 1950.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court had companye to the companyclusion that as the only case set up by the prosecution was that the respondent had migrated before the 26th January. 1950,

facts.text: Supreme Court sets aside acquittal, quashes charge, discharges respondent.

anchor.surface_text: The result is that we allow this appeal and set aside the acquittal of the respondent. We also quash the charge framed against the respondent and order that he be discharged.

facts.text: Trial court observed question of acquiring foreign citizenship post-1950 to be decided by Central Government under Section 9 Citizenship Act.

arguments.claim: Burden of proof under S.9 Foreigners Act immaterial when S.9 Citizenship Act issue arises exclusively for Central Govt.

anchor.surface_text: As no finding can be given by criminal or civil Courts, in a case in which an issue triable exclusively by the Central Government has properly arisen, the question of burden of proof, dealt with in Section 9 of the Foreigners Act, 1946, is immaterial.

holdings.text: The view of the High Court that the only question which need be considered was whether the respondent was an Indian citizen on 26th January, 1950, was incorrect because the charge was not confined to citizenship at the commencement of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: We have, therefore, to examine the charge framed against the respondent so as to determine whether the view of the High Court that the only question which need be considered by it was whether the respondent was an Indian citizen on 26th January, 1950, was correct. We find,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Charge alleges foreigner status at time of 1957 permit and 1967 overstay, requiring determination of post-1950 citizenship loss, not just 1950 status.

holdings.text: The question whether an Indian citizen acquired foreign citizenship between 26 January 1950 and commencement of Citizenship Act 1955 is to be determined exclusively by Central Government under Section 9(2); courts cannot decide it in civil or criminal proceedings.

anchor.surface_text: in view of Section 9(2) of the Citizenship Act, which has been subject-matter of several decisions of this Court See State of Andhra Pradesh v. Abdul Khader 1 Abdul Sattar State of Gujarat 2 and Akbar Khan v. Union of India 3 , the question

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows precedents (Abdul Khader, Abdul Sattar, Akbar Khan) holding exclusive jurisdiction; applies to criminal trials as principle same as civil.

holdings.text: Lower courts rightly held respondent was Indian citizen on 26 January 1950 and migrated to Pakistan post-Constitution in 1953-54.

anchor.surface_text: in the case before us, the finding of the Trial Court as well as the High Court, on the evidence before them was that the appellant had. as he asserted, gone to Pakistan in 1953-54 which was after the commencement of the Constitution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Accepts factual findings of trial and high courts on evidence; distinguishes from pre-Constitution migration cases under Article 7.

holdings.text: Decisive question for the charge is whether respondent was a foreigner at time permission given (1957) and alleged overstay occurred (post-1958).

holdings.reasoning_summary: Charge under Foreigners Act requires proving foreigner status at relevant times, which implicates post-1950 citizenship acquisition under S.9.

holdings.text: No finding can be given by courts if S.9 Citizenship Act issue arises; burden of proof under Section 9 Foreigners Act immaterial.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Exclusive jurisdiction overrides general burden provisions when S.9 question properly raised.

holdings.text: Acquittal cannot be passed without addressing S.9 question; proceedings improper without Central Government determination.

holdings.text: Appeal allowed; acquittal set aside; charge quashed; respondent discharged.

holdings.text: Article 7 exception to Article 5 for migration applies specially to pre-Constitution period; post-Constitution migration governed differently.

precedents.case_name: Akbar Khan v Union of India
precedents.cited_proposition: Courts cannot decide if Indian citizen acquired foreign citizenship; stay proceedings till Central Government decides
precedents.cited_holding: If it was found that the appellants had been on January 26, 1950, Indian citizens, then only the question whether they had renounced that citizenship and acquired a foreign citizenship would arise. That question the Courts cannot decide. The proper thing for the court would then have been to stay the suit till the Central Government decided the question whether the appellants had renounced their Indian citizenship and acquired a foreign citizenship and then dispose of the rest of the suit in such manner as the decision of the Central Government may justify

anchor.surface_text: The result is that we allow this appeal and set aside the acquittal of the respondent. We also quash the charge framed against the respondent and order that he be discharged.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal allowed; acquittal set aside; charge quashed; respondent discharged with liberty to State to prosecute upon decision by Central Government under Section 9 of Citizenship Act
